I‚Äôm also encouraged to know that the Biden Admin is working to address the Trump-era offshore wind leasing moratorium that will put NC‚Äôs ability to develop this resource at risk. Offshore wind is projected to be a $140B industry in the US by 2035, and NC is ready to lead the way.

Overall, these T&I Member Designated projects are a start towards more climate resilient, safe, and racially/economically just transportation systems in our district.

These projects, as part of the bill, are being reviewed in @TransportDems today. Once passed out of the committee, the House Transportation and Infrastructure Bill will go before the House and then the Senate to get passed and signed into law.

The third project included in the T&I bill is about $2.3 million for a @NYC_DOT Northwest Bronx School Safety Improvement Project. 

Sidewalks around two schools in the Bronx would receive necessary improvements to make schoolgrounds safer as we return to on-campus learning.

The second project included in the T&I bill is $13 million for the @NewRochelleNY LINC Project. 

This is for street, bicycle, and pedestrian improvements to connect the Lincoln Ave neighborhood to downtown reducing safety and connectivity issues while boosting economic growth.

The first project included in the T&I bill is about $1.8 million for @CityofYonkers Greenway Project to create a 2.4-mile bike and recreation path from the Bronx to Yonkers. 

This path would give low-income residents access to green space fostering social equity.

‚Äú@POTUS has put forward a visionary budget that will transform our country and create a far better future for all American families.‚Äù <END OF THREAD>

‚ÄúBy pairing the American Family and American Jobs Plans with reforms to ensure that big corporations and the wealthiest Americans to pay their fair share, we can make these powerful, pro-growth investments and set our nation on a fiscally responsible path forward.‚Äù
‚ÄúInvesting in the American people has always been a good bet, but with interest rates this low and the need so high, right now it‚Äôs a sure thing.‚Äù
‚ÄúThen [the President‚Äôs Budget] provides free universal pre-school, which is an enormous benefit to working families.‚Äù

‚ÄúTo ensure parents ‚Äì particularly mothers ‚Äì can safely return to the workforce, provide for their families, and help power our recovery, the budget invests $225 billion over 10 years to make child care more affordable and accessible.‚Äù
‚ÄúIt extends key tax cuts in the American Rescue Plan that benefit lower- and middle-income workers and families ‚Äì like the Child Tax Credit that helped to cut child poverty in half.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe budget also includes the #AmericanFamiliesPlan and proposes long-overdue investments in affordable housing infrastructure, public health and child care infrastructure, expanding opportunities, and creating a fairer, more modern economy in the wake of the pandemic.‚Äù

‚ÄúTogether the plan‚Äôs investments will increase energy resilience and security, lower energy costs for Americans, improve air quality, create good-paying jobs & strengthen U.S. competitiveness‚Äìall while putting our country on the pathway to 100% carbon-free electricity by 2035.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe budget includes @POTUS‚Äô #AmericanJobsPlan, proposing $2.2 trillion in historic investments over 10 years to fix and modernize our failing infrastructure, create good-paying jobs, and revitalize U.S. manufacturing so we can lead the global marketplace.‚Äù

‚ÄúFor too long, self-inflicted austerity has been mistaken for fiscal responsibility, to the detriment of American families and our nation‚Äôs economy. The #BidenBudget ends this era of chronic underfunding and disinvestment in America‚Äôs potential.‚Äù
‚ÄúThat is why @POTUS has proposed a transformative budget that will ensure we emerge from these past 15 months of crisis stronger and better prepared for the future than ever before.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt was the plan our nation needed, and it was a plan this Committee was proud to help deliver. But this is not the time to stop and pat ourselves on the back. Our country is not where we need it to be. There is so much more work to do.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe American Rescue Plan has helped save communities, delivering the resources necessary to get shots into arms, workers back in jobs, and provide lifelines to state and local governments, small businesses, and families.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôd like to take a moment to welcome The Hon. Shalanda Young to our witness table. OMB is well-served to have you at the helm this budget season, particularly given your more than 14 years of experience with @AppropsDems.‚Äù

.@aijenpoo on the #GenderWageGap: "The pandemic has only revealed and deepened inequity for women who were already struggling."

.@RepDonBeyer: ‚Äú‚Ä¶ through policies like the Building an Economy for Families Act, the FAMILY Act, or the Child Care for Working Families Act.‚Äù
.@RepDonBeyer: ‚ÄúWe can‚Äôt make progress towards narrowing the gender pay gap if we don‚Äôt make it sustainable for women to remain in the workforce‚Ä¶

.@RepDonBeyer: ‚ÄúThe Paycheck Fairness Act is one example of a policy that would make it easier for women to challenge pay discrimination. We need policies that help keep women connected to the labor market & moving up the career ladder, such as paid leave & affordable childcare.‚Äù
.@RepDonBeyer: ‚ÄúPolicies that address the ongoing role of discrimination in the labor market will be absolutely necessary to make a meaningful difference in the pay gap.‚Äù
.@RepDonBeyer: ‚ÄúAn important way we can do this is by strengthening the minimum wage and improving workers‚Äô bargaining power, such as through legislation like the Raise the Wage and PRO Acts.‚Äù
.@RepDonBeyer: ‚ÄúRaising wages in low-paying occupations that tend to be dominated by women would provide the greatest benefit to the women in these jobs while also benefiting all workers.‚Äù
.@RepDonBeyer: ‚ÄúAddressing the gender wage gap will require a multi-faceted approach. No single policy is going to close it. But there are many policies that, together, will help narrow it.‚Äù

.@RepDonBeyer: ‚ÄúPerhaps not coincidentally, women of color make up a disproportionate share of care workers. For example, Black women are 13 percent of the U.S. workforce, but 28 percent of home care workers.‚Äù

.@RepDonBeyer: ‚ÄúCare work is among some of the lowest paid work in our economy. The Bureau of Labor Statistics estimates that the median pay for home care aides is $27,080 a year, which is barely above the poverty level for a family of four.‚Äù

.@RepDonBeyer: ‚ÄúWhen seeking to understand the gender wage gap, we cannot ignore the role played by our economy‚Äôs de-valuation of work that has traditionally been done by women, particularly women of color.‚Äù
.@RepDonBeyer: ‚ÄúWhen you add up all the measurable explanations for the gender wage gap... 38% of the gender wage gap remains 'unexplained,' which many economists attribute to discrimination.‚Äù
.@RepDonBeyer: ‚ÄúExplanations that try to explain the gap by pointing to individual characteristics or choices only account for part of the problem.‚Äù

.@RepDonBeyer: ‚ÄúBut while some point to this as evidence that the gender wage gap is due to women making different choices about their careers, the reality is that even within the same industry and same occupation, women are still paid less than men.‚Äù
.@RepDonBeyer: ‚ÄúEconomists estimate that half of the gender wage gap is still caused by differences in the types of industries and occupations that women and men work in.‚Äù
.@RepDonBeyer: ‚ÄúTherefore, if long-term economic growth is our goal, then closing the gender wage gap is not just a moral imperative, it is an economic one.‚Äù
.@RepDonBeyer: ‚ÄúThis is an issue for our whole economy because women‚Äôs lost wages translates into lost GDP, 2.8 percent of GDP to be specific, or $541 billion.‚Äù

.@RepDonBeyer: ‚Äú@IWPResearch estimates that if working women received equal pay with comparable men ‚Äì that is, men of the same age, with the same education, who work the same hours, and live in similar regions ‚Äì then poverty for working women would be reduced by more than 40%.‚Äù

.@RepDonBeyer: ‚ÄúThe failure to close the gender wage gap isn‚Äôt just an issue for the women experiencing this pay gap, it‚Äôs also an issue for their families and for our whole economy. Women‚Äôs earnings are a crucial component of families‚Äô economic security.‚Äù

.@RepDonBeyer: ‚ÄúAnd not only that, but the topline number doesn‚Äôt give us a full picture. Black women earn only 63 percent, Native American women 60 percent, and Latina women only 55 percent of what white men earn.‚Äù

.@RepDonBeyer: ‚ÄúAnd while we have made improvement in narrowing that gap over the last 50 years, progress towards closing it has slowed and even stalled in recent decades as policy has failed to support women as workers and ensure that equal work is rewarded with equal pay.‚Äù

.@RepDonBeyer: ‚ÄúToday, on the eve of the 58th anniversary of the passage of the Equal Pay Act, American women on average still earn just 82 percent of what men earn. That translates to $10,000 in fewer median earnings each year.‚Äù

To close the #GenderWageGap, we need a multi-faceted approach that includes raising wages in low-paying occupations that tend to be dominated by women and/or that are thought of as ‚Äúwomen‚Äôs work.‚Äù @POTUS‚Äô #AmericanFamiliesPlan will do just that.
The $ value of jobs reflects the value we assign them. Updating the value of care work would reduce the #GenderWageGap, modernize our economy, and recognize that care work is infrastructure.

Some of the lowest paid work is care work. Women, especially women of color, are overrepresented in care work. 86% of direct care workers are women, and 59% are people of color. In all but 5 states, the typical home health care worker makes less than a living wage in that state.

But within the lowest-paid occupations, men and women are more equally compensated because of government policies like the minimum wage, which sets a wage floor for all workers. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E3cgceGXIAkvYOE.png

Example: While maids/house cleaners and janitors/building cleaners have similar job descriptions, the avg. maid/house cleaner makes 22% less than the avg. janitor/building cleaner. 84% of maids/housekeeping cleaners are women compared to 33% of janitors/building cleaners.

But even within that half, we know that different $ values are placed on ‚Äúwomen‚Äôs work‚Äù vs. men‚Äôs. To illustrate this we did a rough match based on education/work responsibilities of occupations that are majority male and majority female: http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E3cgX0jXwAIy4LZ.png

It‚Äôs important to note that only HALF of the #GenderWageGap can be directly tied to the impact of industry and occupation ‚Äúchoices‚Äù on women‚Äôs wages, and that share is declining. 

More from @equitablegrowth here: https://equitablegrowth.org/research-paper/gender-wage-inequality/?longform=true

@JesseJenkins @drvolts To be clear, that's not a good thing.  But when we look at new tech that might come on, we shouldn't hold it to a standard (thou shalt earn an acceptable return on capital) that the tech on the grid failed to meet and now set clearing prices accordingly.

@JesseJenkins @drvolts Of those techs, some still run reliably as baseload (nuke) or on the margin (gas), but are, with most exceptions not throwing off enough cash flow to amortize the original investment.

@JesseJenkins @drvolts A case can be made that most of the non-ratebase generation on our grid was built during some period when investors had a too-optimistic view of final capex (post-CAA coal), future $/MWh revenue (90s CCGT) or both (nuke).

@JesseJenkins @drvolts Well, as I said it's a minor quibble.  It's only that the "get it built" tech applies to all generation technologies and is completely separable from the "once built, will it run?" question.   Capex matters for the first Q, but not the 2nd.

Neither the planet, nor our children give a damn about whether or not we acted in a bipartisan fashion.  They care only that we did what was necessary.  This is not the time to back down.  https://www.politico.com/news/2021/06/08/climate-adviser-infrastructure-proposals-492303
11/ But don't confuse a structural problem in the market with a short-coming in any given technology.  Rant over.  And, again, @drvox is super-smart and a great writer.  Just a small quibble.  /fin

10/ By all means, let's keep doing R&D to lower the cost of energy storage technology, and let's figure out how to make sure we provide economic signals to invest in things that the grid - and our climate - need.

9/ Once they were sold out of bankruptcy to new owners (who paid pennies on the dollar) they were good investments.  That's a problem for our power grid, and a structural failure of the way we designed electric markets.  But it's not a statement on the technology.

8/ In the 90s, we built 200 GW (roughly 20% of the entire US power grid!) of combined cycle gas turbines.  Lots of those investors went bankrupt because they never earned as much money per MWh as they thought they would.  But the assets are still there, still running.

7/ And here's the thing: that problem applies to darned near EVERY generation technology.  There's a reason why folks in the power industry like to say "everyone wants to be the third owner of a power plant"
6/ But that's a question about your initial investment thesis, not whether or not the assets are competitive on the margin with other dispatchable generation.  Again, *once built* they will run.

5/ Since more MWh of storage = more hours of discharge, that makes it hard for long-duration storage to pay off it's capital as fast as investors would like.  e.g., you're making marginal money, but may not be keeping up with your debt payments.

4/ So now to address construction costs.  Energy storage systems are, in general pretty expensive to build per MWh of capacity, but pretty cheap per MW of peak power.  Generation technologies (think gas turbines) are the opposite.

3/ In lots of parts of the country, on lots of days, the on-peak / off-peak price differential is > 1.25x.  So - again, with the *once-built* caveat - the technology is already there.  And frankly, that 80% value isn't likely to get much better.

2/ That means that you will run that asset as long as the price you get from selling the electricity is >= 1/0.8 = 1.25x the price you paid to buy the electricity.  Above that point you will make marginal money and knock any more expensive source off the grid.

1/ My view is that for any energy storage system *once built* the only thing that really matters is round-trip efficiency (e.g., how much electricity you get out / how much you put in).  For most battery systems it's around 80%.
